content: WTF is it??? This has been the third time one has been found washed up in the same location. The first time the remains were being saved for identification in a local back yard and mysterously dissapeared. little news coverage. I personally believe its a mutation from experiments being conducted on the secret Plum Island for animimal deseases. Maybe cloning experiments? Its not even allowed to be flown over its so secretive. I once made that mistake and was buzzed by two fighter jets. after flying the reciprical course on the return flight from Groton conn. Its restricted airspace and so marked on the charts. "http://www.montauk-monster.com/"

content: Cloning? You're not serious. To clone something is to make an exact replica (down to the DNA in each cell) of another animal. I find it curious that there is only one daylight still picture at a wierd angle and a one minute 'video' with poor lighting. ONE picture! Who the h#ll takes only one picture with a digital camera these days? And couldn't the guys with the video wait six hours until daylight to do the same "analysis"? This has 'hoax' written all over it. Sullivan013

content: PhoenixDark Posted Fri 15 May 2009 12:17 AM Montauk monster was a hoax - the corpse was likely that of a decomposing (and partially eaten) raccoon 3 different times? Did you look at that head and the hooves? If the papers picked up the stories why wasnt it identified and reporteted as a hoax? It just seems to be reported then goes off the radar till the next time. I will venture to say this wont be the last one. And they all have washed up in the same area and all were identical hooves and beaks. WTF. Think of all the possibilities, But a racoon??? Not even close just by size alone. Maybe even some kind of extinct prehistoric sea creature that has re emerged? Some Years ago commercial fisherman fishing off the deep continental atlantic reef caught a fish they could not Identify and sent it off to the national fishery dept for identication. It was found to be an extinct specie dating back hundreds of years last reported when a sailing ship reported in a captains log sailing for days through miles of these dead fish floating on the surface. They determined that a condition killed off the deep water species and the eggs were preserved deep below. Somethig disloged them or a water temp change hatched the eggs and the species re-emerged and multiplied. It became a popular fish called the tile fish and was in demand due to its delisious taste. That I believe was in the seventies. Its now vanished again an I havent seen it around for years. So there are many possibilities for this new creature and the secrecy surrounding it. A prank?? not hardly.

content: quote: Originally posted by sullivan013: Cloning? You're not serious. To clone something is to make an exact replica (down to the DNA in each cell) of another animal. I find it curious that there is only one daylight still picture at a wierd angle and a one minute 'video' with poor lighting. ONE picture! Who the h#ll takes only one picture with a digital camera these days? And couldn't the guys with the video wait six hours until daylight to do the same "analysis"? This has 'hoax' written all over it. Sullivan013 Cloning? You're not serious. To clone something is to make an exact replica (down to the DNA in each cell) of another animal What we dont know about cloning could fill a library. We do know that they can clone individual organs,and that there are injected substances from stem cell research that can instruct the bodies DNA to reproduce. So given that why is it so hard to believe that they are not experimenting on multiple cloning of different species of animals? Point is we dont know. There has been 3 seperate incidents in the last few years and multiple pictures,each time. If it were a hoax why hasnt it been officially reported as such?? The papers would jump on a story like that to sell a headline. I believe theres much more to it than meets the eye. Keep in mind that Plum Island is a national animal disease research facility and highly guarded and classified. Why would it be such restricted airspace where they would scramble fighters if you penetrate the airspace? Pictures perhaps?

content: I live a very few miles from Montauk. Over the years I have walked and hunted thru the hills of Montauk time and again. Surfed the waves at Ditch Plains and Bea Rielly's Surf and Sand. Camped out at Oyster Pond. Even gone over the old AF Station including the shore batteries bunkers. There are no monsters. BUT, in this economy it DOES increase off season tourism! John's Pancake House and the Circle Restaurant can so testify! Try it, you'll love it!
reply: I live a very few miles from Montauk. Over the years I have walked and hunted thru the hills of Montauk time and again. Surfed the waves at Ditch Plains and Bea Rielly's Surf and Sand. Camped out at Oyster Pond. Even gone over the old AF Station including the shore batteries bunkers. There are no monsters. BUT, in this economy it DOES increase off season tourism! John's Pancake House and the Circle Restaurant can so testify! Try it, you'll love it!

content: quote: Originally posted by john2x: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by L0A1: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: Montauk monster was a hoax - the corpse was likely that of a decomposing (and partially eaten) raccoon. The checked it out on Monsterquest on the history channel. DNA evidence showed it was a decomposed Boxer dog. Let me know I can get a dog with hooves. Pig hooves And a beak. Im sure Walmart can get them on special order. I photograph on beaches two three times a week - Do you have ANY idea what happens to a body that floats around in the ocean for a week or two? Parts fuse, pieces of flesh fall off here and there, and the salt water smooths it all out. I once called in the cops to pick up a dead body, turned out to be a dead seal. And once what I thought was a dead seal was a dead human. And of course, these "monsters" might have had some human help. These creatures, are clearly air breathers, so you're going to say that no one spotted a live one? Dave

content: quote: Originally posted by sullivan013: Cloning? You're not serious. To clone something is to make an exact replica (down to the DNA in each cell) of another animal. I find it curious that there is only one daylight still picture at a wierd angle and a one minute 'video' with poor lighting. ONE picture! Who the h#ll takes only one picture with a digital camera these days? And couldn't the guys with the video wait six hours until daylight to do the same "analysis"? This has 'hoax' written all over it. Sullivan013 Cloning? You're not serious. To clone something is to make an exact replica (down to the DNA in each cell) of another animal What we dont know about cloning could fill a library. We do know that they can clone individual organs,and that there are injected substances from stem cell research that can instruct the bodies DNA to reproduce. So given that why is it so hard to believe that they are not experimenting on multiple cloning of different species of animals? Point is we dont know. There has been 3 seperate incidents in the last few years and multiple pictures,each time. If it were a hoax why hasnt it been officially reported as such?? The papers would jump on a story like that to sell a headline. I believe theres much more to it than meets the eye. Keep in mind that Plum Island is a national animal disease research facility and highly guarded and classified. Why would it be such restricted airspace where they would scramble fighters if you penetrate the airspace? Pictures perhaps?
quote: Originally posted by sullivan013: Cloning? You're not serious. To clone something is to make an exact replica (down to the DNA in each cell) of another animal. I find it curious that there is only one daylight still picture at a wierd angle and a one minute 'video' with poor lighting. ONE picture! Who the h#ll takes only one picture with a digital camera these days? And couldn't the guys with the video wait six hours until daylight to do the same "analysis"? This has 'hoax' written all over it. Sullivan013
reply: Cloning? You're not serious. To clone something is to make an exact replica (down to the DNA in each cell) of another animal What we dont know about cloning could fill a library. We do know that they can clone individual organs,and that there are injected substances from stem cell research that can instruct the bodies DNA to reproduce. So given that why is it so hard to believe that they are not experimenting on multiple cloning of different species of animals? Point is we dont know. There has been 3 seperate incidents in the last few years and multiple pictures,each time. If it were a hoax why hasnt it been officially reported as such?? The papers would jump on a story like that to sell a headline. I believe theres much more to it than meets the eye. Keep in mind that Plum Island is a national animal disease research facility and highly guarded and classified. Why would it be such restricted airspace where they would scramble fighters if you penetrate the airspace? Pictures perhaps?

title: montauk-monster

content: I live a very few miles from Montauk. Over the years I have walked and hunted thru the hills of Montauk time and again. Surfed the waves at Ditch Plains and Bea Rielly's Surf and Sand. Camped out at Oyster Pond. Even gone over the old AF Station including the shore batteries bunkers. There are no monsters. BUT, in this economy it DOES increase off season tourism! John's Pancake House and the Circle Restaurant can so testify! Try it, you'll love it!
reply: I live a very few miles from Montauk. Over the years I have walked and hunted thru the hills of Montauk time and again. Surfed the waves at Ditch Plains and Bea Rielly's Surf and Sand. Camped out at Oyster Pond. Even gone over the old AF Station including the shore batteries bunkers. There are no monsters. BUT, in this economy it DOES increase off season tourism! John's Pancake House and the Circle Restaurant can so testify! Try it, you'll love it!

content: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: Montauk monster was a hoax - the corpse was likely that of a decomposing (and partially eaten) raccoon. The checked it out on Monsterquest on the history channel. DNA evidence showed it was a decomposed Boxer dog. Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns, why should we let them have ideas?" - Joseph Stalin

content: quote: Originally posted by john2x: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by L0A1: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: Montauk monster was a hoax - the corpse was likely that of a decomposing (and partially eaten) raccoon. The checked it out on Monsterquest on the history channel. DNA evidence showed it was a decomposed Boxer dog. Let me know I can get a dog with hooves. Pig hooves And a beak. Im sure Walmart can get them on special order. I photograph on beaches two three times a week - Do you have ANY idea what happens to a body that floats around in the ocean for a week or two? Parts fuse, pieces of flesh fall off here and there, and the salt water smooths it all out. I once called in the cops to pick up a dead body, turned out to be a dead seal. And once what I thought was a dead seal was a dead human. And of course, these "monsters" might have had some human help. These creatures, are clearly air breathers, so you're going to say that no one spotted a live one? Dave

And once what I thought was a dead seal was a dead human. And of course, these "monsters" might have had some human help. These creatures, are clearly air breathers, so you're going to say that no one spotted a live one? Dave
